story.title: Visualizing Page History
story.text: As can be seen by [[Understanding Page History]] this can be complex, containing differing view points - and maybe realities.

story.title: Identity and Provenance
story.text:
[[Forking as (cultural) feature]] raised issues of identity and provenance.

We can see that frances.uk.fedwikihappening.net created the page and directory.fedwikihappening.net forked it, adding commentary. Finding out that frances is [[Frances Bell]], or that directory.fedwikihappings.net is [[Mike Caulfield]], is [[Discoverable but not Obvious]].

FedWiki's neighborhood boundaries are vague and dynamic. But everybody owns their stuff in this network. When should that ownership be more, or less, obvious?

story.title: Identity and Provenance Talk Page
story.text: [[Mike Caulfield]]: Jon, I like this experiment. Of course we'll end up with many different talk pages with 90% overlap, but I think that's OK. I tend to think of conversation here as being like Twitter where it's fine if you see only a portion of the conversation. Forking will always allow you to see what an individual is responding to on a page, which is the main thing.

story.title: Discoverable but not Obvious
story.text: Identity and citation has to be discoverable -- that's part of the deal, the BY in the CC-BY-SA. But it does not follow that citation should be obvious. In fact, there are many reasons to to background citation.

item.title: Visualizing Page History
